Quick tip
Do NOT listen to the tip that you should use sublime. Do use your preferred editor. If you plan to work with ruby on rails you should absolutely use the environment where you feel the most comfortable. I say this because I recommended this video to a friend and they were deeply struggling, not with the language, but with sublime, since the person was very experienced with vscode.

And you might say "Actually you should learn to do stuff REGARDLESS of editor" that's not the case and not what I'm saying either. The world of big frameworks is so extensive that pretending to learn hoy everything works under the hood from the beginning is a terrible idea. The behind the scenes of ruby, as well as any other web technology like Django and Next.js and so on are a complete an utter mess. What I'm saying here is that if you use vscode, you should try to learn how to work with rails on vscode, of you love atom, you should try to learn tk work with it on atom. And he'll if you are one of those very "interesting" emacs/vim users you should also try to learn to work with rails on there! Is not about the editor, is about workflow, and it might be useful to keep using the took you have worked hard to master

replies.author: julu marie
replies.text:
Inside of the <%= yield %> tag on the application layout page, there's a bunch of code that assigns the HTML template created for our INDEX page as the base template for the entire website. Before we made the "Index" page our new home page (by calling the root method discussed at 38:37), the server processed calls to the Index page as GET requests. After we commented out GET 'home/index' and replaced it with ROOT 'home#index', our "index" page became accessible through a root call rather than a GET request.

The latest version of Ruby on Rails requires you to create a separate HTML template for all GET requests. The reason an error occurs when we attempt to load a new subpage (including any subpage with an address like localhost:3000/home/example) is that Ruby must perform a GET request to create this new page. However, our "index" page  is no longer in the request format as it has now become our homepage.

To solve this problem, refrain from commenting out GET 'home/index' on the routes.rb page. This way, the index page will still be accessible through a GET request and can also be called from the root page (the localhost:3000 URL). Hope this helps!

topLevelComment.author: Mheetu
topLevelComment.text:
Great lesson, but there's a few things I'd have changed...

1. Font size, it is waaay too big and the size actually creates more confusion. You have 1/3 of your screen not being used merely because you wanted a white advert behind your cam.
2. Demonstrate good programming practices. I know you're trying to work quickly, but code formatting and indents are important... being a Python guy, you should know that.
3. Keep security in mind... teaching insecure practices is not a good idea. For instance, having the current user's id as a hidden form field is a bad idea. A user could edit the form field's value and insert a friend associated with another user. Instead, get the current user id in the `create` method and use that when inserting the record.
4. Keep performance in mind... rather than filtering query results in the view, change the query to only fetch friends of the current user.
5. Instead of having a conditional to show a pseudo-homepage in the friends index, use the controller to render the appropriate view.
6. "~" doesn't translate to "root directory" but rather the current user's home directory which would be `/home/<usesrname>` or `C:\Users\<username>` on Windows (assuming the OS is installed on C and the user paths have not been altered).
7. Suggesting to not use a password on SSH keys is also not a good idea and they certainly are not "superfluous." The passwords are an added security measure that protect your servers (or w/e the keys are for) from being physically stolen. If a hacker (remote or through in-person social engineering) were to ever gain access to your SSH keys, your servers' security would be compromised if there isn't a password on your keys.

As for why GitHub has changed the default branch from 'master' to 'main'... it's part of their effort to use more "inclusive" language. If you're insistent on using 'master', you can change your default branch name in your GitHub settings.

The authorization structure using " before_action :correct_user, only: [:edit, :update, :destroy]" will not work for the update method (2:47:30). An attacker would be able to modify the POST request to /friends/:id with a different user’s “friend[user_id]” in the body of the request. This would allow user 1 to add a friend to user 2’s account if user 1 changed the friend[user_id] client-side. The @friend.nil? logic would only work if it is incorrect (being that its not incorrect at the time of running is where the problem lies, so it’s sort of a logic flaw. Checking the parameter with the expected user in that method would fix that. To replicate change the ID value in an edit request (client-side) and watch it get re-assigned to another user.

I don't normally comment on these, but as someone who works with Rails on a daily basis, I have a piece of advice. For folks working on Windows, just an FYI: Use Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL). It makes the *entire* first section of this video go smooth as butter by comparison. WSL lets you run bash/zsh natively using an actual Linux kernel instead of relying on git bash. Doing it this way, you'll need to follow setup/installation steps recommended for linux users (i.e. install RVM and pull in ruby/rails through that so your ruby version is locked down. DON'T USE THE CANONICAL PACKAGE, it will very very likely be wildly outdated. Use RVM or rbenv or asdf or whatever flavor of version management catches your fancy)
That said, avoid developing baremetal in Windows. You're setting yourself up for headaches down the road. Sure, it can be done, but should you? Probably not if you can avoid it. At least not where Rails is concerned. Hope that helps someone since the first bit sounded kinda doom and gloom when it doesn't have to be that way.
